title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #573: Extremal Numbers for {C₃, C₄}-free Graphs**

**Question:** Is ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ~ (n/2)^(3/2)?

**Status: OPEN**

The extremal function ex(n; F) counts the maximum edges in an n-vertex graph avoiding all subgraphs in F. This problem asks about forbidding both triangles and 4-cycles.
mathContext: Part of Turán-type extremal graph theory, connecting to the celebrated Kővári-Sós-Turán theorem.

title: Triangle-Free Predicate
content:
**isTriangleFree G:**

A graph G is triangle-free if no three vertices form a complete subgraph K₃.

Formally: ∀ a b c, ¬(G.Adj a b ∧ G.Adj b c ∧ G.Adj c a).

Triangle-free graphs include all bipartite graphs.

title: C₄-Free Predicate
content:
**isC4Free G:**

A graph G is C₄-free if it contains no 4-cycle.

Formally: for any four distinct vertices a, b, c, d, we don't have a-b-c-d-a forming a cycle.

C₄-free graphs are central to the Kővári-Sós-Turán theorem.

title: Extremal Function ex(n; {C₃, C₄})
content:
**exC3C4 n:**

The maximum number of edges in an n-vertex graph that is both triangle-free and C₄-free.

This is defined as a supremum over all valid graphs.
mathContext: The extremal function is a fundamental object in Turán-type problems.

title: Kővári-Sós-Turán Theorem
content:
**kovari_sos_turan:**

ex(n; C₄) ≤ (1/2)n^(3/2) + (1/4)n

This 1954 theorem gives the asymptotically tight upper bound for C₄-free graphs. The matching lower bound comes from projective plane constructions.
mathContext: One of the cornerstones of extremal graph theory, proving ex(n; K_{s,t}) = O(n^{2-1/s}).

title: The Main Conjecture
content:
**erdos573Conjecture:**

ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ~ (n/2)^(3/2) as n → ∞.

This is formalized as: for all ε > 0, there exists N such that for n ≥ N,
|ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) - (n/2)^(3/2)| ≤ ε · n^(3/2).

The problem asks if this conjecture is true.

title: Upper Bound
content:
**exC3C4_upper_bound:**

ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ≤ (1/2)n^(3/2) + (1/4)n.

This follows from:
1. ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ≤ ex(n; C₄) (more restrictions = fewer edges)
2. ex(n; C₄) ≤ (1/2)n^(3/2) + O(n) by KST

title: Lower Bound
content:
**exC3C4_lower_bound:**

There exists c > 0 such that ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ≥ c · n^(3/2).

Constructions using incidence graphs of projective planes achieve near-optimal bounds. These are bipartite (hence triangle-free) and C₄-free.

title: The Asymptotic Gap
content:
**Why This Matters:**

- KST gives ex(n; C₄) ~ (1/2)n^(3/2)
- The conjecture claims ex(n; {C₃, C₄}) ~ (n/2)^(3/2) = (1/2√2)n^(3/2)
- The gap is a factor of √2 ≈ 1.41

The question is whether adding the triangle-free constraint reduces the leading constant.

title: Summary: OPEN
content:
**erdos_573 and erdos_573_summary:**

**STATUS: OPEN**

The problem cannot be resolved by finite computation - it concerns asymptotic behavior.

**What we know:**
- Upper bound from KST
- Lower bound from constructions
- The exact constant remains unknown
